fields.description:
Gerrit (which we switched from to Stash) allows the batching of comments before submitting as a single notification. I had a large pull request with > 100 files changed and my teammate commented on a lot of the files which I got a large thread for in Mail.app which is fine, but I cannot recomment on each one, because that sends him an email for each that he doesn't want since he doesn't thread emails. This turns into an unintentionally passive-aggressive situation since it isn't painful to the person using threaded email views, but it is a huge pain point to those that need to use unthreaded email views in their mail reader, so one person can comment freely and the other can't without causing a deluge of crap in the non-threaded folks inbox.

However, if we turn off notifications, then he won't know that I commented. So, there needs to be a way to make a number of comments and then send the notification, somehow. I had thought of suggesting that Stash provide an hourly digest of messages, but that wouldn't be immediate and could slow down development. However, if comments are send as a batch in a notification, then there is the change that they would not be sent unless I submitted them, so would require more significant UI/UE changes to the process of commenting.

This is the most painful thing I've run into with Stash so far, and I think it will take some thought about the user experience to come up with something that will both allow real-time commenting and limit tons of notifications being sent without requiring email to be read in threads. Thanks for any consideration and assistance!
fields.summary: Don't send a notification on every pull comment immediately

fields.description:
The [Connecting to JIRA for user management|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+to+JIRA+for+user+management] lists steps for user directories order and user/groups for Stash in JIRA.
[The JIRA integration screens in the setup Wizard|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Configuring+JIRA+integration+in+the+Setup+Wizard] do not include these steps though, leading to an incomplete JIRA configuration.
The following is customers feedback from a support ticket to help improve this integration via the setup wizard:
{quote}
I have figured out how I got into the mess where Stash thought there were 2 JIRA instances. The very last step in the Stash install asks do you want to manage users via JIRA (or something to that effect). I said yes, which Stash then registered itself as something like 'Generic Application - IP-ADDRESS - BIG RANDOM NUMBER WITH 60-100 digits'. It created the link between Stash and JIRA so that Stash could logon. However, it didn't do everything and even though the [test] button will work for that server - it doesn't place that server first in the Directory Path nor does it setup the necessary permissions. [Step 3. Set up Stash users and groups in JIRA] in this URL https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+to+JIRA+for+user+management. Therefore since the JIRA logons weren't working when I found this URL - I followed all the steps, which included adding the JIRA User Directory - thus I had 2. This document needs to say something - like - if you didn't say (YES) in the stash wizard do steps 1&2 or if you said (YES) skip to step3. Although it would be nice if it had a note on how to change the Generic Application... string recognizable. By doing an edit on the 2 entries it describes in steps #1 and #2 so that Stash logs in as 'Stash' Application not the big long random string. And editing the JIRA Users/ Other applications to accept 'Stash' instead of the big ugly long random string.

Lastly, answering [Yes] in the Stash wizard should create the groups and/or permissions recommended in step #3 and it should swap the order of the User Directory to make JIRA first. Unless I am not understanding something still.
{quote}
fields.summary: JIRA integration steps missing from setup wizard

fields.description:
Every now and then, a random directory listing page will give me an error saying that README.md doesn't exist in that directory. If I accept the default action on that popup, I get bounced all the way back up to /projects/

This happened most recently when I was clicking "Back" really fast to go back up a tree; maybe it's looking for an object that's been expunged when the data on the page got reloaded?
fields.summary: Readme rendering triggers an error when navigating repository

fields.description: At our company we would like to create our own internal Atlassian hosted environment similar to Atlassian OnDemand with Stash instead of Bit Bucket.  This would only be used by teams within our company and they would be responsible for handling their own backups.  This isn't a problem for tools like JIRA where you can perform a backup manually via the UI, but Stash doesn't currently allow for this so we wouldn't be able to give them their own instance without also giving them shell access so they can manage backups.  Providing this functionality via the UI and the REST API would give teams the flexibility to schedule automated backups as well.
fields.summary: Ability to perform backups via web UI and REST API
Can tab, return submit comments?

fields.description:
I think that someone already suggested having the last commit message next to each file in the files view, but something that would be really nice is something on top of the files view with the somewhat shortened version of the last commit message and link to the last commit and username who made the commit.

Here's why:

The #2 thing I need to do in Stash (behind having to review other people's pull requests or click to merge an approved pull request) is to choose the repo, then choose the branch and click on pull request, but before I do a pull request, I'd like to make sure that I chose the right branch. Seeing the last commit was from me and what I committed gives me some confidence that I chose the right branch without having to click on the commits tab.

(This could be done as part of the other ticket that suggested to put last commit message for each file into the files view, maybe? Please don't litter it up with user pics though!)

I love Stash. It has a lot going for it and is loads better than gerrit code review!
fields.summary: Suggestion to show last commit atop the files view of repo
Adding a web-section to Repositories menu causes recently viewed repos to display twice

fields.description:
This is a continuation of STASH-2076.

When using {{java.io.File}} to open files with Unicode characters in their names, encoding issues sometimes cause {{exists()}} to return {{false}} even for files which do exist. This results in {{NoDefaultBranchException}} being thrown even when the default branch does exist (and is resolved correctly by {{git}}).
fields.summary: Default branches with Unicode filenames don't resolve reliably

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of March 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

I'm excited to share that in Bitbucket Server 7.0 we shipped redesigned and optimized pull request page with several improvements you’ve been asking us, including syntax highlighting in unified diffs.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.0 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html] and Pull Requests [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/review-and-discuss-a-pull-request-808488540.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original request description*

Need syntax highlight in "diff to previous" and pull request
fields.summary: Support syntax highlighting in unified diffs

fields.description:
When running the {{start-stash.bat /fg}} from the Windows command line, if {{JAVA_HOME}} is set to something like {{C:\Java\bin}}, the batch script appends an extra {{\bin}} resulting in something like {{C:\Java\bin\bin}}. This will fail to start Stash but [no error message is produced|^screenshot1.png] nor shown in the logs.

Should this be something that should be addressed in the path checks or should it be mentioned in the documentation instead?
fields.summary: Windows Batch Script Improvement to Output JAVA_HOME Path Errors

fields.description:
Similar to github's deployment key feature (https://help.github.com/articles/managing-deploy-keys) it is sometimes desired to have a non-public repository which contains sensitive information which some automation would deploy to a system.  For this, each system could generate an ssh keypair which would be used for deployment/read-only purposes.

This JIRA is a followup to a comment thread for STASH-2508 seeking this feature.
fields.summary: add support for deployment ssh keys

fields.description: It'd be cool if viewing a file in the diff view would mark it as viewed (like Crucible). I don't always look at changes from top to bottom, and I forget where I've looked.
fields.summary: Track read and unread files in a pull request

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Do not modify {{Dintegration.jira.key.pattern}} (previosuly {{Dstash.jira.key.pattern}} - see STASH-2784)
# Integrate Bitbucket Server with JIRA
# Perform a commit to Bitbucket Server with the comment 'TST3-123' (The issue column does not have JIRA issue link)
# Stop Bitbucket Server
# Modify JIRA custom issue key regex by editing the {{setenv}} script:
{noformat}
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS="-Dintegration.jira.key.pattern=\"b([a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]+-\d+)\""
{noformat}
# Start Bitbucket Server
# Perform another commit to Bitbucket Server with the comment 'TST3-123'
 
h3. Expected Results
Previously pushed commits have the issue link.

h3. Actual Results
Only the latest commit has the issue link.
fields.summary: The latest custom JIRA issue key regex is not used to reindex the old commits

fields.description:
Seemingly confusion around time zone regarding time-stamp of commit actions: I committed code change from my workstation, of which the date/time is Thu Jun 14 10:49:51 EST 2012. The time of the code change came out as "13 Jun 2012" (no time-zone information was given) on Stash UI. I assume that was the Stash server's time, although end-users may expect the time to reflect the actual moment they conducted the commit, i.e. the time (along with time-zone) they see on the machine where they did the commit.

I guess at the minimum we should include time-zone information on Stash UI.
fields.summary: Support User Timezones
Provide configurable whitespace settings on the diff view

Make the file path in Stash easy to copy

fields.description:
at the moment the git repo description must set manually via the description file in every git repo. the repos are named by id (see: STASH-2552) so it is very extensive to update the descriptions.

it would be very handy to have a possibility to update this description file via stash.
fields.summary: set git repo description by stash

fields.description:
This is related to STASH-2646: Seb notes that commits aren't tied to a branch, but branches can view commits. If we can't display what branch a commit was originally tied to, would it be possible to see a list of public branches that can view that commit?

The use case here is when someone says "here is my commit" and gives you the stash link. So you go and see the commit, but on that page there is no way to know if this commit is going to be released in the next release, because you can't see what branch(es) include that commit.
fields.summary: It would be nice to be able to see the branch a given commit was on

fields.description:
The pull requests are a nice feature, but not only do we still need to delete branches manually (see issue STASH-2753), it is also not possible to squash the new commit into the target branch.
We would like to have a clean history that doesn't show any parellel commits in our main development and master branches.

It seems that this is relatively easy to implement, since it is a new button and a few extra git commandline calls. But that is from a user point of view.
fields.summary: Option to squash commits when merging a pull request

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Can't see the Diff between files with permission changes
j and k keyboard shortcuts don't respect "Your una...

fields.description:
Permissions set at the user level do not apply if permissions at the project level is more lenient. 

For example, I have a project that has a default permission of read/write. I set up a user that only has "observer" access to the project. This user is able to push code to the repository even though they only have the "observer" status. 

If I change the permissions to be "observer" or "no access" at the project level, the "observer" user can no longer push code which leads me to believe the individual permissions aren't really being applied at all.

I think permissions should be checked at the individual level first before checking it at the project level.
fields.summary: Permissions at user level not working

fields.description:
[gerrit|http://code.google.com/p/gerrit/wiki/Background] has the concept of Verifiers in addition to Reviewers.

Verifiers are - in general, though they can be humans fulfilling a role - tools that perform some form of verification on the code in a review and then approve it like a Reviewer.

It would be nice if Stash would be able to run an arbitrary program and based on what it returns, approve or disapprove a Pull Request.

If the Verifiers for a Pull Requests failed, then the any merge would require an override.

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: Add "Verifiers" ala gerrit for Pull Requests

fields.description: It would be really a great feature to stash if customers could easily move a repository from one project to another by using the web GUI.
fields.summary: Possibility to move a git repository from one project to another

fields.description: In the commit list, it's will be very helpful to see the tags (git), like BitBucket does!
fields.summary: Show tags in commit listing

fields.description:
When a conflict exists in a pull request, a warning appears within the "Overview" tab with a link labeled "More Information".  Clicking the link will bring up the "How to manually merge a pull request" dialog.

The 3rd step says to commit the changes and push using the following commands (replaced internal references with *):
{code}git commit -m "Merge pull request #* from *-* to integration" --log --no-ff 
git push origin HEAD{code}

I believe "--log --no-ff" should occur in the previous step, while using the merge command.
fields.summary: Invalid commit command on the "How to manually merge a pull request" dialog

fields.description:
Our product development group is divided into different focus areas with each focus area then having multiple different products that they develop.  What we'd like to be able to do is create a high-level project for each focus area and then have a project per product underneath that high-level project.  Each product could then have 1 or more repositories.  So we'd like to see support for a project hierarchy of at least 2 levels added to Stash.

I did look at STASH-2727 which is for creating project categories - this may allow us to do something similar to what we need depending on how it was implemented and how permissions could be granted across categories.
fields.summary: Support for sub projects

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of October 2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

This suggestion is a priority for the Bitbucket development team and is on our roadmap, however we're not able to provide a timeline for when it will be resolved. [Learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,
Anton Genkin

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

I'm thinking it could make sense to be able to give a user or group global read-only permission (to the Git repositories). This would be beneficial if you have a build server user that wants to grab code from your Stash managed Git repositories.

I've noticed you already have an Oberserver-role on a project level, but I don't think this exists on a global level. It's a bit of a hassle to give the "TeamCityBuildServer" user the Observer role on every new repository.
fields.summary: Be able to give a user or group global read-only permission

When the project creator creates a new project, the button for creating a new repository is visible in the new project, but not in the project that existed at the time of granting rights.

fields.description: The ability to create a JIRA ticket from any comment in Stash would significantly speed up the review workflow.
fields.summary: Create a JIRA issue directly from the comment thread

fields.description:
If possible I'd like to see the ability to comment on existing code without doing so in the context of a Pull Request. I believe this would help facilitate discussion around code, I.e. refactoring suggestions, possible bug identifications, etc.

An extension to this would be to create a JIRA issue directly from the comment thread.
fields.summary: Commenting on code outside of a Pull Request
markdown good.
awesome smilies/emoji

fields.description:
JIRA has a [UI|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA050/Configuring+Project+Keys] to help specify a custom issue key format.

Stash can allow JIRA integration with custom issue key formats by editing the {{<STASH_INSTALL>/bin/setenv.sh}} or {{<STASH_INSTALL>/bin/setenv.bat}} depending upon the OS.
To do this, pass {{-Dstash.jira.key.pattern=<some different regex>}} parameter to the {{JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}} property, such as:
{noformat}
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS="-Dstash.jira.key.pattern=(<Some different regex>)"
{noformat}
It would be good to make this configurable via the UI instead.
fields.summary: Document specifying a custom JIRA issue key regex

fields.description:
There are two issues with SAL PluginUpgradeManager deployed in Stash.

# It is not exposed via OSGi as {{LifecycleAware}}, so it's onStart() method is never called (so upgrades are not triggered on startup).
# It implements {{DisposableBean}} and {{InitializingBean}}, but {{afterPropertiesSet()}} and {{destroy()}} are also not called. This due to the fact that sal-core is exported from the host application which is using Spring 3.x, so the plugin system (using Spring 2.x) doesn't recognise the versions of {{DisposableBean}} and {{InitializingBean}} when it does it's "assignable from" comparison.
fields.summary: SAL UpgradeTask framework doesn't work in Stash

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. If you're really passionate about this suggestion, please comment with your case in detail and we'll reconsider. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center

fields.description: I'm still new to Git, but from what I understand you may want to set git config options like "receive.denyDeletes" and "core.logAllRefUpdates" when working with a shared remote repository. Stash should allow setting config options on a hosted repository.

fields.description:
When reviewing a pull request, you can add a comment to any *line* of a changed file.  I think there are at least two pieces of functionality missing:

1. Adding a comment at a file level.  I know one could arbitrarily choose the first line of the file to make such a comment, but this doesn't work if the file is empty (Stash shows the message "No change was found for the file at this revision.").

2. Adding a comment at a folder level.
fields.summary: File Comments on Pull Requests

fields.description:
It would be great if Stash could do diffs/dry-run merges of multiple developer branches, and identify future merge conflicts before they happen. The pull request idea is great for figuring out merge conflicts with master, but what about merge conflicts with new work being done on other branches? They'll all get merged into master at some point.

In the following scenario, the VP of Engineering wants everyone to commit to master, in order to prevent merge conflicts down the line, so devs will know immediately if they're stepping on someone else's toes. But this means we're treating git just like subversion, trading 'svn update' for 'git pull --rebase'. If we can check for merge conflicts between existing non-master branches, we could give him what he wants and still maintain the functionality of Pull Requests.
fields.summary: Diff for merge conflicts in development branches

fields.description:
The addition of pull requests is a nice step in the right direction, but what would really set the Atlassian suite apart, and make my life a lot easier, would be to have really strong integration through the whole development cycle for a particular issue.

The biggest thing that's missing right now is the integration between pull requests and JIRA issues. In general, a pull request will probably be related to some particular issue. During development, there will be some comments relating to speccing out the issue and probably some code-review type comments on the pull request itself. It would be beyond convenient if all of those were connected into one discussion. There might be multiple pull requests involved in a single issue, and they should be linked with statuses on the issue itself.

It's a pain to have the discussion, code review, and resolution split between the issue and the pull request. They need to all be integrated together.
fields.summary: JIRA issue / Stash pull request integration

fields.description:
I'm loving Pull Requests so far -- I can definitely see us adopting a 'branch for every story and issue' approach.

However, the downside to that is you will end up with a LOT of branches in Stash. They can be manually removed from a git client (like SourceTree).

What I would like is to have a Pull Request that can optionally delete the branch after the merge. This is a great way of marking that issue/story as completed and merged, because its then removed.

(I appreciate that there is no need from a git point of view to remove the branch, but for a human perspective of having to look at a gigantic list of branches, it is desirable.)

This is somewhat related to STASH-2491 as that relates to using branches for release/issue management.
fields.summary: Option to delete a branch after pull request merge

fields.description:
Support for shortcuts to submodules (http://git-scm.com/book/en/Git-Tools-Submodules) while browsing the source.

Consider also future mercurial support (STASH-2469) for subrepositories (http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/Subrepository)

Github supports this by allowing history browsing to recurse into subrepositories, but I'm guessing a simple hyperlink (parsing repo URL and adding the link as a "virtual" folder in source browsing) would suffice.
fields.summary: Git Submodule Support

I'm still not sure what happened. I was running an old version. I stopped the service. But the service kept running (it shouldn't have).

Then I uninstalled the service, installed the service for a newer version, and started it.  The old java proc was still running, but the new service started fine anyway (it shouldn't have).

Then I did stuff, thinking I was using the new version, but clearly I was not.   Finally realized I had some rogue javas, killed those, and restarted the service with a fresh stash home.  Works fine now.

I'm running Kostya's distro of 1.2.0.

This is starting from a clean STASH_HOME.

I can provide a copy of the STASH-HOME as-is if you need.

Stash version dbd354e994cb86799a4a45b84ff9fe8d4d06a608 <--- this is the old version I was running.

fields.description: In Confluence and JIRA, when an unknown user (one that has not logged into the instance previously) logs into the instance while backed by Crowd, a one-time user lookup occurs that will pull the user and group memberships into cache during the authentication.  Stash currently does not have this functionality built into it's authenticator class.
fields.summary: Crowd connector does not do a one-time check when user does not exist in the DB cache

fields.description:
When viewing the Branch Diff for a Pull Request the Branch Diff sometimes shows *all* the differences between the two branches, not just the changes from the commits in the to-be-merge branch.

This doesn't happen every time, and when I attempted to create a simple example the problem didn't occur.  However I have seen it a number of times when I have a branch that diverged quite some time ago from the main branch.

Our main branch is named "develop" (following the Git Flow model) and a feature branch may look like "feature/my_feature".  In the Pull Request "feature/my_feature" is to be merged into "develop" which had 20+ commits.

The feature branch only had changes to a few files, all named "Makefile", but the Branch Diff shows every file changed over time in the "develop" branch and the diff colors indicate that the changes made to "develop" will be reversed (to the same status as the *unchanged* file in the feature branch).  (stash13-a.jpg attached)

The commit tab (stash13-b.jpg attached) shows only the few changes to files named "Makefile".  A manual merge of the two branches (external to Stash) only changes the committed changes in the feature branch and do NOT make the changes that the Branch Diff indicates will be made.
fields.summary: Branch Diff in Pull Requests sometimes shows "reverse" diffs

fields.description:
Stash is requesting it's own default avatars through gravatar. When HTTP access to the server is limited, it results in errors while downloading avatars.

What happens is that Gravatar is trying to access Stash's URL, gets 401 Unauthorized which is transformed into 400 Bad request on its side and causes browser's errors. 

Not a big deal, but still...
fields.summary: Default avatar URL through Gravatar on secured network

fields.description:
The limitation of 64 characters for the repository name and URL is too short.
It would be better to increase this limit to 128 characters.
fields.summary: Increase the Character Limitation For the Repository Name From 64 to 128

fields.description:
I accessed stash using localhost:7090 on my server and created a new user.

The welcome email sent to the user contained http://localhost:7990/passwordreset?token=<TOKEN_HERE>

The base url is configured correctly to the public name of the server.

As soon as I accessed the user admin UI again using the configured base url the email sent to users contained the correct address.
fields.summary: Wrong base url in emails sent to newly created users.

fields.description: It might be useful to be able to download an entire repository as of a certain commit, rather than individual files.
fields.summary: Download entire repository as of a certain commit, rather than individual files

fields.description:
We have documentation on [Running Stash as a Windows service|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Running+Stash+as+a+Windows+service], but not for Linux.

[What is the best way to autostart STASH on linux debian/ubuntu platform|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/52897/what-is-the-best-way-to-autostart-stash-on-linux-debian-ubuntu-platform] addresses this in the meantime, but would be ideal to have an recommendation from Atlassian.
fields.summary: Running Stash as a Linux service

fields.description:
It's a bit painful to understand what commits or comments you haven't read since the last time you were in Stash. 

Each PR in the Open tab should have an indicator if there's been comments or commits added since you've viewed it last.
fields.summary: Show new content when visiting a pull request
